Ni-doped titanate CsxTi2-x/2Nix/2O4 and its protonic deriv. HxTi2-x/2Nix/2O4·xH2O (x = 0.7) were synthesized and characterized by synchrotron x-ray diffraction, Raman scattering, XPS, and magnetic measurements. CsxTi2-x/2Nix/2O4 crystallizes in an orthorhombic structure (space group Immm), consisting of infinite two-dimensional (2D) host layers of the lepidocrocite (γ-FeOOH) type. The substitution of Ni atoms for Ti in the 2-dimensional octahedral layers results in neg. charges that are compensated by interlayer Cs+ ions. Raman scattering and XPS indicate that local structural perturbations are induced upon exchange of interlayer Cs ions with protons H3O+. Magnetic measurements reveal typical paramagnetism induced by Ni substitution; the effective paramagnetic moment μeff = 1.57(1) μB and Curie-Weiss temp. -2.51(1) K were obtained for HxTi2-x/2Nix/2O4·xH2O. Ni- and Mg-codoped titanates CsxTi2-x/2(NiyMg1-y)x/2O4 (x = 0.7, 0 ≤ y ≤ 1) are also reported. The crystal structure, interlayer chem., and magnetic properties of the titanates depend on the Ni substitution levels, indicating opportunities for tuning of the properties by controlling the nature and level of lattice substitutions.

Synthesis of Mn-Substituted Titania Nanosheets and Ferromagnetic Thin Films with Controlled Doping
Dong, Xiaoping; Osada, Minoru; Ueda, Hidekazu; Ebina, Yasuo; Kotani, Yoshinori; Ono, Kanta; Ueda, Shigenori; Kobayashi, Keisuke; Takada, Kazunori; Sasaki, Takayoshi

The authors report the synthesis of Mn-substituted titania nanosheets and the prepn. of room-temp. ferromagnetic thin films via layer-by-layer assembly of these nanosheets. Ti(5.2-2x)/6Mnx/2O2 (x = 0.0-0.4) nanosheets were synthesized by delaminating layered titanates [K0.8Ti(5.2-2x)/3Li(0.8-x)/3MnxO4], in which the Mn content was systematically controlled by Li+ doping. Mn content in the host layers was preserved upon exfoliation, and controlled Mn doping was achieved in exfoliated Ti(5.2-2x)/6Mnx/2O2 (x = 0.0-0.4) nanosheets, where Li+ ions were completely extd. by acid-exchange reaction in the exfoliation process. The multilayer films of Ti(5.2-2x)/6Mnx/2O2 (x = 0.0-0.4) nanosheets exhibit a clear magnetic hysteresis loop at room-temp. in similar to what obsd. in ferromagnetic Ti1-xCoxO2 nanosheets. Electronic absorption, MCD, and hard XPS were used to identify Mn-derived states, and analyze the properties of these states related to ferromagnetism. The 1st-principles calcn. of Ti(5.2-2x)/6Mnx/2O2 was also employed to characterize the doping effect on electronic structures.

Fe-Doped Nanostructured Titanates Synthesized in a Single Step Route

div.div:

55
Fe-doped nanostructured titanates synthesized in a single step route
Costa, A. M. L. M.; Marinkovic, B. A.; Suguihiro, N. M.; Smith, D. J.; da Costa, M. E. H. M.; Paciornik, S.
Materials Characterization
(
2015
),
99
(
),
150-159
CODEN:
MACHEX
; ISSN:
1044-5803
.
(
Elsevier
)
In this research nanostructured titanates, contg. iron in the structure, were obtained through a single-step alk. hydrothermal route aiming at redn. of band-gap energy. In the process, a Fe-Ti rich Brazilian mineral sand was mixed with 10 M of NaOH and then submitted to isothermal treatments at temps. ranging from 110 to 190°C in an autoclave. The as-obtained products were water-washed and then characterized by transmission electron and scanning transmission electron microscopies, X-ray photoelectron, M.ovrddot.ossbauer and diffuse reflectance spectroscopies. Transmission electron microscopy analyses showed a morphol. dependence of the product as a function of the temp., i.e., titanate nanosheets were predominantly formed at lower temps. (110°C-150°C), while nanoribbons, with some nanosheets and nanoparticles, were the main products at higher temps. (> 150°C). Using energy dispersive X-ray it was detd. that iron was incorporated into nanosheets. On the other hand, the as-obtained nanoribbons were Fe-free, while iron was principally assocd. with nanoparticles attached to the nanoribbons. By means of X-ray photoelectron and M.ovrddot.ossbauer spectroscopies, it was elucidated that iron adopted Fe3+ form in the as-prepd. nanosheets, occupying octahedral sites inside the titanate lepidocrocite-like structure. Diffuse reflectance spectroscopy showed a change of absorption pattern from nanosheets to nanoribbon/nanoparticle assembly: nanosheets exhibited high absorption from UV up to the visible light range, while the nanoribbon/nanoparticle assembly demonstrated a drop in absorption in the visible light range. These results suggest that Fe3+ incorporation inside the titanate structure is responsible for enhancing the visible light absorption, making these nanosheets potentially suitable for applications in photoinduced processes.
